--- Ian Badcoe <ian_badcoe@...> wrote:
> 
> >The inputs will be a sequence of N random binary
> >patterns of M bits each.  N & M will be parameters
> and
> >we will begin with very small values, then raise
> them.
> >  The patterns will be presented sequentially,
> i.e.,
> >not simultaneously.  There is at least one
> additional
> >input which is a control input to let the net know
> >that the sequence has ended.  Hence there are M+1
> >binary inputs.  After the sequence has ended then
> the
> >net is expected to repeat it.  Don't forget that a
> >recurrent ANN can be a signal generator; that's
> what
> >is supposed to happen here.  The ANN will generate
> a
> >sequence of outputs that is supposed to reproduce
> the
> >input sequence.
> >
> >There are also M+1 outputs.  M of these are
> supposed
> >to replicate one of the input patterns during the
> >"recall" phase.  The other output is a "ready" line
> >indicating that the output is valid or that the net
> >has completed its processing.  During the initial
> >presentation of the sequence the ready output is
> used
> >to indicate that the net is ready to accept the
> next
> >pattern.  The other outputs are ignored during this
> >phase.  In the second, or "recall" phase, the ready
> >output signals that the pattern is ready to be read
> >from the pattern outputs.
> 
> This is very interesting experimental design.  Did
> you also consider 
> inputting the start sequence with indices (e.g. M
> inputs for data and N 
> inputs for "address" -- probably just setting one
> address-line high, not 
> full binary numbers) and then ask for the data back
> by repeating the 
> address sequence.

No.  That would be a different problem, also worth
doing.  I'm modeling phone dialing; you hear a phone
number, 7 sounds in sequence, then after only a very
short delay you repeat it back in the same sequence,
either by speaking it or dialing it.
 
> One other question, you say start small and scale
> up, but to get back to a 
> thread from a couple of weeks ago, do you have any
> way of carrying progress 
> over from a net evolved for small examples to larger
> ones?

Yes, I simply don't re-initialize the population, or
maybe I re-initialize a large part of it, but I keep
those ANNs that did well on the smaller problem.

> >This is very similar to what is done by my 4Play
> >program, except 4Play did more complex logic than
> just
> >repeating memorize values.
> 
> I'd say this was asking for a more complex net,
> however...

Which do you think is more complex?
